title: Photo Tagging Over Time: A Longitudinal Study of the Role of Attention, Network Density, and Motivations

author: Paul Russo, Polytechnic Institute of NYU

segmentation: Hi everyone, to Rousseau here.
Thanks so much for having us and thanks to the reviewers for all their comments.
Today we're going to talk about tagging overtime and specifically looking at Flickr.
I wrote this paper.
It was it.
Was it lucky opportunity.
My doctoral advisor, Oded, Nov, had some data and he was decided to push me.
He said, you know, this has to be in by January.
It was.
It was December 15th.
It was a very busy three weeks, but so that being said.
Several studies have shown that participation in online communities wanes overtime and that if you don't do something to sustain it, it continues to get worse until eventually the community dies.
So in this paper we want to look specifically at a a type of participation and that is tags or meta information.
So we in general look at what kind what.
What influences the participation of tags?
Overtime we had three, three very general ideas, attention.
Network structural properties and individual motivations.
This is this is going to be a longitudinal study.
We did it over 90 days and we looked at actual system data, sorry.
We looked at actual system data and combine that with motivations so we could look at behaviors as opposed to simply what people said they do.
We have 3 research questions.
1st about individual motivations, and then we asked about receiving attention as we talked about.
And of course density.
But Interestingly we were able to look at interaction effects and I think in some ways that is one of the most interesting parts of the paper, and we'll get to that at the end.
Eat.
So this is a snapshot of Flickr.
It's a photo sharing site, and it's also a social networking site.
On the site you have pro so you have pro users and amateurs.
We specifically focused on Pro users who had a tenure of over three months.
This way we could avoid the notion of people who are just who are new and getting excited.
We wanted serious people who were in the community for awhile.
Now on Flickr you can create Contacts and will talk about what that means, 'cause it's important to this paper.
You can join groups.
This is something we eventually want to look at.

You can give comments, you can add testimonial using comments about the person testimonial.

They tag for themselves, and they tag for others.
For themselves a the goal is to find a way for to archive and retrieve better so so you know where your photos have been after a long time.
But for others, perhaps it's with searching, but it's also describing so when the individual looks at a photo, they have a sense of what's inside.
And we do it.
We do our constructs from other studies, previously one by Venkatesh and one by Wasco and Farage.
So now attention.
There are many ways to give people attention.
Views, comments, testimonials you can friend them like them, dig them, rate them.
You can rate ratings.
A paper by Uber, a couple of papers by Uber Uberman Romero and Wu.
They were able to demonstrate that on YouTube that as users are uploaders, got attention in the form of views.
They continue to upload more and that there was almost a continuous continuous cycle or a feedback loop, so that participation was state sustained.
Then these people posted more and more and more.

You choose to follow someone.
You make them a person of interest now.
Hi Miss Lovinggood Marty, what they saw was that in fact usually people just reciprocate and form a bidirectional link, so that makes it easier for our calculations.
And they are and Miss Lovinggood.
Marty and some other people also found that there's a network by proximity bias.
People choose their friends.
Within one or two network hops of each other, so you're starting to get people who sort of know each other.
There's a reason these people, when they're together, they know each others, and they do that based on similar likes and dislikes.
And it's it's a type of a monthly.
And what happens?
This overlap begins to create some sense of common knowledge, and I think you can see where this is going if everybody that's in the cluster shares a lot of the same knowledge.
Then perhaps it's not so important to tag.

Describe your photo.
I take the energy to describe photos for people who already probably know what's in them.

We think that enjoyment, commitment and attention should positively impact tagging.
Anne.
And on the other hand, we think density or the tighter network should decrease tagging.

The number of public photos that were added and the reason we do this is because, again, we have evidence that ultimately as people add more and more and more photos, the average number of tags per photo will decrease.
OK, so and Lastly I should say again we think this is important is there are interaction effects in specifically interaction effects between density and attention and density and commitment?
OK.
This was a longitudinal study.
Over 90 days on Flickr.
Um?

So as we thought about people.

There's another idea which you know I don't have enough, it's it's simply an explanation.

There's a reason they're in your ego network.
I wonder if attention from your friends mean something more.
